content.question: A GRAPHING CALCULATOR IS REQUIRED FOR THIS QUESTION. You are permitted to use your calculator to solve an equation, find the derivative of a function at a point, or calculate the value of a definite integral. However, you must clearly indicate the setup of your question, namely the equation, function, or integral you are using. If you use other built-in features or programs, you must show the mathematical steps necessary to produce your results. Your work must be expressed in standard mathematical notation rather than calculator syntax. Show all of your work, even though the question may not explicitly remind you to do so. Clearly label any functions, graphs, tables, or other objects that you use. Justifications require that you give mathematical reasons, and that you verify the needed conditions under which relevant theorems, properties, definitions, or tests are applied. Your work will be scored on the correctness and completeness of your methods as well as your answers. Answers without supporting work will usually not receive credit. Unless otherwise specified, answers (numeric or algebraic) need not be simplified. If your answer is given as a decimal approximation, it should be correct to three places after the decimal point. Unless otherwise specified, the domain of a function <math alttext="f"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is assumed to be the set of all real numbers <math alttext="x"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> for which <math alttext="f of x"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> is a real number. Let <math alttext="f"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> be the function defined by <math alttext="f of x, equals, the cosine of, open parenthesis, the square root of x, close parenthesis"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mi>cos</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mrow><mo>(</mo><msqrt><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></msqrt><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>. (a) Approximate the definite integral <math alttext="the integral from, 1 to 3, of, f of x, d x"><mrow><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mrow><mstyle><mrow><msubsup><mrow><mo>∫</mo></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msubsup><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>ⅆ</mo><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></mrow></math> using a midpoint Riemann sum with the subintervals <math alttext="open bracket, 1 comma 1.6, close bracket"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>[</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>1.6</mn><mo>]</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="open bracket, 1.6 comma 2, close bracket"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>[</mo><mn>1.6</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>]</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>, and <math alttext="open bracket, 2 comma 3, close bracket"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>[</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>]</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>. Show the work that leads to your answer.

frqParts.text: A GRAPHING CALCULATOR IS REQUIRED FOR THIS QUESTION. You are permitted to use your calculator to solve an equation, find the derivative of a function at a point, or calculate the value of a definite integral. However, you must clearly indicate the setup of your question, namely the equation, function, or integral you are using. If you use other built-in features or programs, you must show the mathematical steps necessary to produce your results. Your work must be expressed in standard mathematical notation rather than calculator syntax. Show all of your work, even though the question may not explicitly remind you to do so. Clearly label any functions, graphs, tables, or other objects that you use. Justifications require that you give mathematical reasons, and that you verify the needed conditions under which relevant theorems, properties, definitions, or tests are applied. Your work will be scored on the correctness and completeness of your methods as well as your answers. Answers without supporting work will usually not receive credit. Unless otherwise specified, answers (numeric or algebraic) need not be simplified. If your answer is given as a decimal approximation, it should be correct to three places after the decimal point. Unless otherwise specified, the domain of a function <math alttext="f"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is assumed to be the set of all real numbers <math alttext="x"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> for which <math alttext="f of x"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> is a real number. Let <math alttext="f"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> be the function defined by <math alttext="f of x, equals, the cosine of, open parenthesis, the square root of x, close parenthesis"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mi>cos</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mrow><mo>(</mo><msqrt><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></msqrt><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>. (a) Approximate the definite integral <math alttext="the integral from, 1 to 3, of, f of x, d x"><mrow><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mrow><mstyle><mrow><msubsup><mrow><mo>∫</mo></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msubsup><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>ⅆ</mo><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></mrow></math> using a midpoint Riemann sum with the subintervals <math alttext="open bracket, 1 comma 1.6, close bracket"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>[</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>1.6</mn><mo>]</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="open bracket, 1.6 comma 2, close bracket"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>[</mo><mn>1.6</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>]</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>, and <math alttext="open bracket, 2 comma 3, close bracket"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>[</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>]</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>. Show the work that leads to your answer.

(b) Approximate the definite integral <math alttext="the integral from, 1 to 3, of, f of x, d x" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mrow><msubsup><mo>∫</mo><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msubsup><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>ⅆ</mo><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mrow></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></mrow></math> using a trapezoidal sum with the subintervals <math alttext="open bracket, 1 comma 1.6, close bracket" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>[</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>1.6</mn><mo>]</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="open bracket, 1.6 comma 2, close bracket" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>[</mo><mn>1.6</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>]</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>, and <math alttext="open bracket, 2 comma 3, close bracket" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>[</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>]</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>. Show the work that leads to your answer.

(c) It is known that <math alttext="f prime of x, equals, the negative of, the fraction with numerator the sine of, open parenthesis, the square root of x, close parenthesis, and denominator 2 times the square root of x, end fraction"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><mo>−</mo><mfrac><mrow><mi>sin</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mrow><mo>(</mo><msqrt><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></msqrt><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn><msqrt><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></msqrt></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="f double prime of x, equals, the fraction with numerator the sine of, open parenthesis, the square root of x, close parenthesis, and denominator 4 x times the square root of x, end fraction, minus the fraction with numerator the cosine of, open parenthesis, the square root of x, close parenthesis, and denominator 4 x, end fraction"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>″</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mi>sin</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mrow><mo>(</mo><msqrt><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></msqrt><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn><mi>x</mi><msqrt><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></msqrt></mrow></mfrac><mo>−</mo><mfrac><mrow><mi>cos</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mrow><mo>(</mo><msqrt><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></msqrt><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn><mi>x</mi></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mstyle></math>. Would a trapezoidal sum approximation for <math alttext="the integral from, 1 to 3, of, f of x, d x"><mrow><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mrow><msubsup><mo>∫</mo><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msubsup><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>ⅆ</mo><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mrow></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></mrow></math> overestimate or underestimate the value of <math alttext="the integral from, 1 to 3, of, f of x, d x"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mrow><mstyle><mrow><msubsup><mrow><mo>∫</mo></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msubsup><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>ⅆ</mo><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> ? Give a reason for your answer.

(d) Write <math alttext="the integral from, 1 to 3, of, f of x, d x"><mrow><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mrow><msubsup><mo>∫</mo><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msubsup><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>ⅆ</mo><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mrow></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></mrow></math> as the limit of a right Riemann sum with <math alttext="n"><mstyle><mrow><mi>n</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> subintervals of equal length.

skill.text: Skill 1.F: Explain how an approximated value relates to the actual value.
